Award.AwardTitle: CRCNS: Long Term Reactivations in Cortex and Hippocampus

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding how memory is encoded and maintained in our brain is paramount to understanding cognitive functions. Unlike in a computer, human memories are continuously consolidated, reconsolidated, and integrated within the context of what has already been learned. This process is thought to involve exchanges of information between the cortex and the hippocampus during sleep. The investigators will study the ability of small groups of cells in the rodent hippocampus and medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) to become transiently co-active during sleep periods occurring many hours after learning has taken place. Rats will be engaged in learning tasks aimed at selectively activating one or both of these areas. It is expected that the activity recorded during post-task sleep will be correlated with the activity of the same cells during the task in a manner compatible with the nature of the task and the specifics of the learning. This type of reactivation is considered to be a basic mechanism for memory consolidation.

The investigators have developed new analytical tools based on fuzzy clustering and information geometry. Preliminary data show that short episodes of reactivation occur with different time courses in these two structures, as is often proposed on theoretical grounds. In this project, the investigators will study how this reactivation is coordinated across two connected brain areas (CA3-CA1, CA1-mPFC) on very long time scales, and how single neurons contribute to single reactivating episodes.

These studies will yield insights into the long-term temporal and spatial dynamics of reactivation in the adult rodent. They will also contribute to a better understanding of the neural basis of memory consolidation and reconsolidation in cortex and hippocampus, and the relationship between memory consolidation and sleep.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Memories are formed in an iterative manner. After the initial acquisition of information, they are stored in short term memory, and then periodically reactivated as new information is further acquired and consolidated in long term memory. These reactivations allow for the integration of new memories with older ones. This reconsolidation process occurs throughout the life time of the memory. Studies in rodents have shown that individual neurons involved in a learning task indeed reactivated during slow-wave sleep epochs immediately following the task. This reactivation occurs during short oscillatory events called Sharp Waves Ripples complexes (SWRs) and takes the form of recurring patterns of cross-correlations between multiple pairs of neurons. These patterns are similar to that induced by the task, indicating that reactivation is a network phenomenon that is rooted in the awake learning experience and that persists during subsequent sleep. Typically, this reactivation has been detectable up to one hour after post-task sleep onset.

In this work, we made the theoretically-driven hypothesis that reactivation should in fact occur well beyond the initial hour. We surmised that the reason why most research could not measure reactivation beyond the first hour was because the measurements were conducted on the entire population of cells recorded. We hypothesize that most cells contribute to reactivating memories initially, but that reactivation progressively focusses only on a subset of cells. We also hypothesized that the underlying nature of reactivation in short-term and long term-memory storage was different.

To test this hypotheses, we conducted long term recordings of populations of neurons in two areas known to be involved in spatial learning and memory. We used two new neural data analyses techniques. The first termed ‘fuzzy spike train clustering’ is leveraged from techniques used in the field of Artificial Intelligence. It aims at robustly finding subgroups of neurons exhibiting partial synchrony during the learning task. The second termed ‘Information Geometry’ (IG) is leveraged from techniques used in the field of Probability Theory. It aims at providing an orthogonal decomposition of neural interactions at multiple levels (beyond pair-wise) and at estimating the underlying functional neural architecture such as synaptic interactions.

 

Intellectual Merits:

Several significant results were obtained in the course of this research.

1) We improved on the fuzzy spike train clustering methods and made it available to the community. Over 60 downloads have been recorded to date.

2) We introduced a new spike train metrics (used by the clustering algorithm) that addressed significant deficiencies of the existing metrics in the field, including their poor ability to recognize periods of inhibition and periods of bursting as significant similarity features,

3) from the data collected, we showed that small clusters of neurons could reactivate up to 11 hours after the task, well beyond the 1 hours previously observed.

4) We introduced two variations of the original tasks and were able to show that SWRs may have several computational modes depending on synchrony levels at multiple recording sites, with asynchronous states driving internal consolidation and synchronous states driving the communication with cortical areas.

5) We demonstrated that the IG measures were robust estimators of two key network parameters: Average intrinsic connection strength between recorded neurons, and average amount of external inputs to the network.
